info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 55.

(Jimmy: Howdy!  Come along and sing some cowboy songs, next on Jeopardy!  Come on, let's go!)

(1, 1).clue: The Declaration was adopted in this city

(2, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew sits upon a white mare on a dude ranch in Montana.)  A seldom heard later verse of this song goes:"Oh I love those wild flowers in this dear land of ours"

(3, 1).clue: Some say this tool with an adjustable jaw was invented by a Massachusetts mechanic named Monk

(5, 1).clue: Total number of each animal that Moses took on the Ark with him during the great flood

(6, 1).clue: In 1975 Dick Cheney became this president's Chief of Staff

(1, 2).clue: The Declaration does not mention this supreme legislative body of Great Britain by name

(2, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew belts out a tune from atop a horse on a dude ranch in Montana.)  Dale Evans wrote the lyrics to this song that says:"Until we meet again"

(3, 2).clue: Santa Claus might know that this word comes from the Scandinavian for "creature" & the Old English for "beast"

(5, 2).clue: The number of times you can subtract 5 from 55

(6, 2).clue: From 1995 to 2000 Cheney was CEO of this energy services firm

(1, 3).clue: It says that if this denies people their rights, the people have the right "to alter or abolish it"

(2, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew belts out a tune from atop a horse on a dude ranch in Montana.)  It’s where Gene Autry was in the title of his theme song:"Out where a friend is a friend"

(3, 3).clue: This ovoid term for an intellectual was often used of 1952 presidential candidate Adlai Stevenson

(5, 3).clue: An insomniac dyslexic agnostic lays awake all night wondering if there really is one of these

(6, 3).clue: Dick Cheney was born in this city that's home to the University of Nebraska

(1, 4).clue: This British Lord’s 1993 novel "Honor Among Thieves" concerns a plot to steal the Declaration

(2, 4).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew sits upon a brown horse on a dude ranch in Montana.)  A dying cowboy made this request:"These words came low and mournfully"
(2, 4).correct response: bury me not on the lone prairie

(3, 4).clue: An early recorded mention of the phrase "busy as a bee" appeared in this 1387 Chaucer work

(5, 4).clue: The 2 U.S. coins that add up to 30 cents when one of them is not a quarter

(6, 4).clue: In the first President Bush's cabinet, Cheney was Secretary of this

(1, 5).clue: After all the states ratified it, Congress added this 9-letter word to the title

(2, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew sits in the saddle of a brown horse on a dude ranch in Montana.)  In this song, a cowpuncher in a hurry sings:"It’s your misfortune and none of my own"

(3, 5).clue: Once eaten only on Church holy days, this fish's name is from English & Dutch words for "holy flatfish"

(5, 5).clue: Total number of balls used in the pool table game called 8-ball

(6, 5).clue: Dick Cheney served 6 terms as this state's sole representative in the House of Representatives

(1, 1).clue: In 1493 Christopher Columbus discovered this future U.S. commonwealth & named it San Juan Bautista

(2, 1).clue: Adjective meaning completely expressionless used to describe Jackie Vernon’s or Steven Wright’s comic style

(3, 1).clue: It's the numerical name for a traditional canopy bed

(4, 1).clue: Born October 2, 1869 in Porbandar, India, didn't eat much, died January 30, 1948 in New Delhi

(5, 1).clue: In 1964 Coco Chanel & Norman Norell were championing the right of women to wear these

(6, 1).clue: We hope your dog doesn't suffer ennui when boarded in one of these establishments

(1, 2).clue: In 1855 this missionary discovered Victoria Falls on the Zambezi River

(2, 2).clue: On "Coffee Talk", on "SNL", Linda Richman (this man in drag) would get "farklempt" ("choked up" in Yiddish)

(3, 2).clue: Get your mind out of these troughs & try using your hands or a hose to clean out the leaves

(4, 2).clue: Born in Oklahoma in 1879, had a lot of laughs, died near Point Barrow, Alaska in 1935

(5, 2).clue: The sarong that Edith Head designed for this star in 1936 was widely copied for beachwear

(6, 2).clue: Get thee to this synonym for a convent

(1, 3).clue: On June 18, 1767 Samuel Wallis became the first European to land at this breadfruity South Sea island

(2, 3).clue: "Who's Who in Comedy" quotes our 1989 clue "Married couple who've done commercials for Blue Nun wine…"

(3, 3).clue: If you have the room, this structure seen here is a fine addition to any backyard

(4, 3).clue: Born around 1507, married a king & gave birth to a future queen, died 1536 in London

(5, 3).clue: It's the name for the loose, brightly colored dress introduced to Pacific islanders by missionaries

(6, 3).clue: Manually sifting for gold in a river

(1, 4).clue: This Dutch explorer also discovered Tonga & Fiji in 1643

(2, 4).clue: Riddle me this, he starred on Broadway in 2002 doing his impression of George Burns

(3, 4).clue: Jerry Garcia fans unite! This is the practice of removing those old withered flowers from your garden

(4, 4).clue: Born in St. Louis in 1888, became a Brit in 1927, wrote poems & plays, won a Nobel Prize in 1948, died 1965

(6, 4).clue: A chronological record of the events of successive years

(1, 5).clue: This 5,140-square-mile Venezuelan lake was discovered in 1499 by Alonso de Ojeda & Amerigo Vespucci

(2, 5).clue: In the '70s his act was called "Child of the '50s"; in 2000 his HBO special was "Child in His 50s"

(3, 5).clue: Usually off-white with rugged loops, this type of carpeting is named for one made by North African tribes

(4, 5).clue: Born Belfast 1824, gifted scientist, whole life remembered as an absolute zero, died 1907

(6, 5).clue: In 1777 the Green Mountain boys had a hand in winning the Battle of this city in Vermont

(0, 0).clue: The 2nd-smallest independent country in area in the Western Hemisphere; in the '80s it was invaded by the 2nd largest
